text: hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new / / Sun
record terrestrials terrestrials is the
new collaborative project from two huge
names from the darker side of music
drone metal and doom metal titans sun
they've been coming out with some of the
boldest heaviest and most uncompromising
records in this genre since the early
2000s and considering they started out
as an earth tribute band I think over
time they've really come together with
their own unique take on the style of
music through records like black 1
monoliths and dimensions and alter and
on this record Sun is coming together
with over one of the most diverse bands
that Norway has to offer whose lineup
over the years is just as sporadic as
their sound their discography is filled
with songs that fit snugly into black
metal dark ambient electronic music and
trip-hop folk music chamber music dark
jazz and after every stylistic turn over
has taken over the years they've put out
at least one or two records that seems
to have been a big hit with the band's
fanbase and the metal world at large but
my personal favorites from the band's
discography are their first three
records all of which are black metal
classics in my opinion and I guess in
2008 over linked up with Sun in Norway
in over studio while son was in the
country for a live gig and while getting
together so spontaneously to just lay
out some sort of improvised pieces
sounds really awesome I was kind of
apprehensive about this album when I
went into it after reading the back
story of it because on the one hand if
this music was really some of Suns and
overs best wouldn't the LP be longer it
really only stands at 30 minutes and
wouldn't there be more tracks wouldn't
they have put this thing out earlier
considering it was recorded in 2008 I
was sort of afraid that this record
wouldn't be anything more than just a
fan favourite or collector's item versus
a pinnacle in either band's discography
but on the other hand the last major
collaborative LP that Sun came out with
altar with bore
this is one of their best albums one of
Boris's best albums - so there is reason
to believe that putting son together
with a group that's just as creative and
interesting if not more will just create
amazing results no matter how long the
record is no matter how many tracks are
on it and while I wasn't disappointed in
this thing I did end up sort of on the
fence with terrestrials on the whole I
ended up wanting more length out of this
thing I ended up wanting some of the
tracks here to just be a little bit more
climactic but still I think Sun and
overcame together and made something
that was sort of unique something that
they wouldn't have done separately which
is really one of the best things you can
hope for when going into a collaboration
between two really established artists
so if you are even a casual fan of
either band here I do think terrestrials
is at least worth checking out just for
the exploration 'el aspect there are
moments on this LP where foundationally
and conceptually it feels like a son
song but over comes through and lightens
up the drones a little bit making the
sounds more ethereal harmonious and
delicate like on the opener here let
there be light this song is not really
the massive overpowering wall of sound
you typically expect from a son album
but I still thought the track had its
moments and and really eased me in to
the record there are all these
high-pitched tones swelling in and out
of the mix as well as these tremolo
tones and underneath this horns and
strings are slowly introducing
themselves into the mix and all of the
instrumentation just slowly grows and
fills in the gaps that they're creating
until the song just becomes massive vast
all of this sort of becomes a foundation
for this wandering fluttering trumpet
bring in the song kind of a jazzy flavor
and that's fine it's it's not bad it
doesn't ruin the track when I think the
song really gets a little underwhelming
is toward the finish line when drums are
introduced and they're so blue body
lists there are these heavy guitars
playing against them too and you know
while I appreciate the idea of coming
together with an explosive finish
payoff is is really hardly there on the
flip side there are moments on this LP
where it feels like I'm listening to an
over song which son is bringing in some
really meaty heavy elements like the
closing track on here eternal return
probably my favorite track on this
entire LP I love the icy vibraphone on
this track if that is vibraphone that
I'm hearing
I'm loving the strings the ethereal
guitars this track is just so wide and
expansive and panoramic it's like
standing on top of the mountain just
looking down and out on to everything
that just stands before you and below
you and the chords on this track just
have a really really strong jazz
influence to them and the pace that
they're played at sort of reminds me of
boron doc rah-rah and the transition
this track makes from the first half to
the second half is stellar string
sections pop in and they're skipping
very lightly against the tempo that the
band is set for the track there's some
heavy piano chords some cold
synthesizers and Christopher rigs vocals
come in sound so smooth yet a little
unnerving after hearing this track and
hearing this side of the Sun over
spectrum eternal return is really the
the place that I think this record could
have explored further explored for more
tracks or at least for more time there
is the song western horn on this LP as
well which is sort of a meaty middle
ground between that over sound and that
Sun sound it's not bad but it's not
really a stunner either it's heavy but
not that heavy it's got a lot of layers
of instruments but I wouldn't call this
track beautiful or anything like that
this is really one of the darker more
disturbing tracks on this entire LP the
guitars are so grotesque they're all
these mangled distorted tones calling
out throughout the song - there's some
really cold synthesizers there are some
really cold keyboards as well and a
really odd whistling sound that feels
like a mix between the baby from
Eraserhead screaming and a teakettle
going off and this sound weaves in and
out in a really weird way and is most
apparent right at the finish of the song
I like this LP I
thought it was good I didn't think it
was amazing it's got its moments
I don't feel like it pushes the fringes
too hard for either artist or the genres
that these songs play in but I still do
find terrestrials appealing for the sort
of improvisational lightning in a bottle
appeal that comes with Sun and over
deciding to collaborate so suddenly the
production is great it's well-balanced
it's colorful the music is big it's
Moody it's slow it's monolithic it does
what it's got to do I'm feeling a strong
six to a late seven on this thing
transition if you given this new Sun
over collaboration to listen what did
you think of it
did you love it did you hate it why and
what do you think I should I don't know
review next hmm Anthony Fantana son and
over terrestrials forever
